utterances: Well, I want to say, you know, in our household, it's always our money, never my money or her money, regardless of who makes the most.
My wife is a part-time stay-at-home mom.
She's a massage therapist, so she spends sometimes taking care of the kids and then sometimes working.
But another thing I would mention was about motorcycling.
A lot of motorcycle industries are starting to gear more motorcycling toward women because it's a growing market.
And do you have a motorcycle, Shane?
Oh, I do, and I had to get my wife's permission to buy it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Actually, you'll be interested to know that I ride a Harley.
Right, well, and you know, two wheels is two wheels.
Yeah.
Yeah, yeah.
Yeah, that's a possibility Jim.
I suspect that may be true.
Thanks very much for the call.
Let's go to Zack.
Zack is with us from Jacksonville, Florida.
Hi, how are you doing?
Thanks for taking my call.
Sure.
And I mean it's just, you know, motorcycling is fun, and you see a lot of the magazines are really gearing it towards women: just riding gear, riding clubs, you know, all-women riding schools.
But in our household, you know, it's never my money, regardless of if I make more.
The fact that she doesn't work and stays at home, she keeps us from spending money, so that's like earned money.
That's a way to think of it, Shane.
That's an interesting...
Well, absolutely, and she saves us from spending money, and that's making money, so less going out means more staying in.
And it's an equal field, regardless of who makes more.
It's, you know, it takes two people or more to raise a family.
Shane, thanks very much for the call.
Appreciate it.
You're welcome, guys.
Have a good day.
Bye-bye.
And Jody DeVere, I wanted to thank you for your time today.
Thank you.
Jody DeVere, president of Ask Patty, a Sarasota-based Web site providing advice for female auto consumers, and she joined us today from KNPR, our member station in Las Vegas.
And let's get another call up for Marti Barletta, the CEO and founder of the TrendSight Group.
And this is David.
David's calling from Fort Wayne, Indiana.
Hi, can you hear me okay?
Yeah, we can hear you, David.
Go ahead, please.
Well, my question is, if women are buying so many things, why do so many products designed to look so ugly?
It seems like they're designed to cater to men.
Like what, do you think, David?
Well, for cars, for example.
So many cars have this great big gaudy big grill in the front.
They almost resemble some big dog, and it's not really necessary to design it like that.
Uh-huh.
A lot of stereo equipment.
I couldn't buy a new stereo because they all had these huge, gaudy knobs, and it's not necessary.
They can all be switches, little push buttons, sleek design.
So...
There are so many things that are designed to look like they cater to men.
So Marti Barletta, are designs going to change as manufacturers realize that - where the purchasing power is?
Well, I think a couple of things are going to change.
I certainly hope the designs are going to change.

I'm a little surprised at how little - there are entire industries of people who are in the design business in Detroit and in California and in auto companies all over the world, and yet in my opinion I share David's observation.
I think that there are so much opportunity to do a much, much better job in design for automotive.

What's interesting about automotive, speaking of the differences between women and men, is that generally the automotive companies, when they ask about styling, one of the things they found out is that styling to men means what the car looks like on the outside, whereas styling to women, they tend to think more about what it looks like on the inside.
So the finishes, the knobs - as David was talking about - the burlwood, the brushed chrome, the leather or the seats, etc.

And so I think there's a tremendous amount of upside for the manufacturer that figures out how to do that, and I just - you know, I know it's hard to make a car, but if Dell can make a computer overnight, I don't understand why you can't make a car and offer some options for color, you know, that - any color you want except for black.
We're not that far advanced from Henry Ford's original design template.

So I also think that the automotive - which cars people - women buy are going to change significantly, because as the Baby Boomers move into the sort of post-family age - I've got another book coming out in January called Primetime Women, which focuses on women who are 50 to 70 years old.

And the - because Baby Boomer women are coming out of the primetime stage, I predict that we're going to see a move away from SUVs - which we have finally started to see acknowledged by the auto companies.
Even though SUVs have been trailing off for over a year, they're finally starting to say, hmm, I wonder if that 10-year upward trend is still going to continue - which it's not.

But what they are going to sell more of are luxury cars, sports cars - to Jody's point, women enjoy these cars - and I believe mini-cars, like the, literally Minis and Volkswagen Beetles, the cute cars, as it were.
David, thanks very much for the call.
I do have another example.
Go ahead.
One of the few cars that I find was very nice looking and elegant styled was the Oldsmobile, which is no longer made.
Right.
Thank you very much.
All right, David.
Thanks very much.
Here's an e-mail we got from Hazel in Illinois.
Here's what happens when the woman doesn't get a chance to do research.
We were shopping a few weeks ago and my husband saw a great deal on TV, which we did need.
I asked him if this was really the TV he wanted.
He said yes.
Well, when we got it home he opened it up and discovered it is made for Canada and therefore does not comply with U.S.
digital TV requirements.
It is not returnable and now we're stuck with it.
Well, hope you're enjoying hockey night.

Jim's with us from Spencer, Iowa.
Hello.
Good Afternoon.

Hemi?
Oh, you name it.

Hmm.
That's interesting.
